RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - METRO POOL CHEMICALS, INC.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Metro Pool Chemical, Inc. stores and utilizes chlorine for swimming pool activities, which is considered a hazardous material that is a regulated substance and the facility has established a Risk Management Plan (RMP) according to EPA's regulations (40 CFR Part 68) for the chlorine Storage to enhance its already existing safety programs. Metro Pool Chemicals is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very diligent about safety for its employees, visitors and its neighbors. The facility's staff is well trained and utilizes modern equipment to provide safeguards.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Metro Pool Chemicals, Inc. has an emergency response plan in place to handle potential emergency situations at this facility. This plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

Key elements of the Emergency Response Plan include specific steps that Metro Pool Chemicals management expects of its employees to take to protect health of the employees, visitors and the neighbors. The Emergency Response Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, key phone numbers and contact points, vicinity and evacuation maps,
and instructions for evacuation and for actions to be taken in case of a fire, injury, earthquake and chemical spill. The Plan is reviewed and updated periodically to ensure that it remains current.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The chlorine tank consists of a double walled storage tank, a transfer pump, piping, valves and scrubbers that are used during the filling operation. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Metro Pool Chemicals has a Risk Management Program in place to manage the handling of chlorine. The program includes strict requirements fo

r written operating procedures, personnel training, equipment maintenance, incident investigation, process hazard analysis, management of change and periodic review or audit of program elements. Written procedures are developed
as part of this program that specify the steps for every task undertaken related to the chlorine system. Management of change element addresses proper implementation of system updates to ensure that all changes are reviewed properly by knowledgeable persons, all operating procedures reflect the change, and personnel are trained on the change. The RMP also requires a pre-startup safety review to ensure that the system is properly reviewed before it is put back into service after a major change. In addition to the RMP, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are strictly followed.

Five Year Accident History

The five-year accident history (July 2019 to July 2024) for the Metro Pool Chemicals facility reveals that there were no reportable accidents during this period.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Metro Pool Chemicals is taking additional steps to further public and personnel safety. Several studies have been conducted recently to examine potential release scenarios and effectiveness of existing mitigation measures and to take additional steps to further enhance safety. All recommended changes have been reviewed and implemented.
